Title.evidence: This was an open, multicentre, randomized controlled trial.

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients with intermittent claudication attending vascular surgery outpatient clinics were randomized (1:1)

Participants.evidence: Patients with intermittent claudication attending vascular surgery outpatient clinics

Intervention.evidence: randomized (1:1) to receive either neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) or not in addition to local standard care

Objective.evidence: The objective of this trial was to investigate the clinical efficacy of an NMES device in addition to local standard care in improving walking distances in patients with claudication.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was change in absolute walking distance, measured by a standardized treadmill test at 3 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients with intermittent claudication attending vascular surgery outpatient clinics were randomized (1:1)

Blinding.evidence: This was an open, multicentre, randomized controlled trial.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 160 were included in the primary analysis (intention to treat, Tobit regression model).

Result_Outcome.evidence: SET as local standard care seemed to improve distance compared to best medical therapy at 3 months (3.29 units; 95 per cent c.i., 1.77 to 4.82; P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: No serious adverse events relating to the device were reported.

Funding.evidence: This trial was supported by a grant from the Efficacy and Mechanism Evaluation Program, a Medical Research Council and National Institute for Health and Care Research partnership.
